items.title: 'Died in the hands of her father': Negin is one of thousands of Iranians killed
items.description: Like so many Iranian Australians, Morteza Khandani has been desperate for any news of his family in Iran. Two days ago, he was able to confirm the worst. His niece, Negin Ghadimi, had been killed in anti-government protests.

items.title: Millions of accounts culled days after social media ban started, data shows
items.description: More than 4.7 million Australian social media accounts have been deactivated since laws banning children aged under 16 took effect in December, according to data released by the government.

items.title: Greens won't support Labor's sweeping hate law reform in current form
items.description: The Greens have thrown up a roadblock for Labor by declaring it will not support the government's sweeping changes to hate and gun laws without amendments as the Coalition also backs away from the reforms.

items.title: Politicising Bondi backfires for Liberals who got what they asked for
items.description: Federal Liberals are discovering the price of having been so brazen in their politicisation of the Bondi terror attack and many appear to have buyers' remorse.

items.title: Pulp agree to Adelaide Festival show after apology to Randa Abdel-Fattah
items.description: Pulp had been among the acts prepared to boycott the festival over the cancellation of a slot with the Palestinian-Australian author at Adelaide Writers' Week.

items.title: Cars washed to sea, rain record smashed in Great Ocean Road deluge
items.description: People in a popular holiday region have been issued with an emergency warning after a storm cell dumped more than 100 millimetres of rain, flooding campsites.

items.title: Trump threatens to invoke Insurrection Act over Minnesota anti-ICE protests
items.description: Such a move would allow the president to deploy troops to quell persistent protests in the city of Minneapolis, where two shootings connected to immigration crackdowns are fuelling public anger.

items.title: Workers lose pay, super as NDIS provider collapses
items.description: Up to 500 workers are fighting to recoup pay, super and entitlements after the collapse of a large disability support provider operating in New South Wales.

items.title: 'Night owls' less likely to find antidepressants effective: new study
items.description: A major Australian study finds standard antidepressants are not effective for around 20 per cent of people, who may need alternative treatments.

items.title: Hong Kong fire killed 168 people in total, authorities confirm
items.description: The final death toll is seven higher than previously reported and comes months after the fire tore through the apartment complex.

items.title: Wikipedia is 25, but some old fights are still going
items.description: Wikipedia is celebrating 25 years of the online encyclopedia and the enormous impact its had, while looking forward to its future. But some controversies from the past refuse to die.

items.title: Premier announces review into Victoria's disastrous bushfires
items.description: Jacinta Allan vows to request a formal review of the state's disastrous bushfire season, following days of questions over issues like Country Fire Authority resourcing and the state's disaster preparedness.

items.title: Astronauts return to Earth in NASA’s first medical evacuation
items.description: A capsule carrying four International Space Station crew members has splashed down in the Pacific, bringing their mission to an end more than a month early.

items.title: Second fatal crane collapse tied to same Thai firm, minister says
items.description: A second fatal crane collapse in two days has been linked to the same construction company, a Thai minister says.

items.title: Behind Grok's mass digital undressing lies an 'unsurprising' truth
items.description: The X AI is not creating sexually explicit images of women on its own, but the software "facilitates their abuse" acting on the requests of men "eager to violate women".

items.title: Adelaide Festival Corporation apologises to author Randa Abdel-Fattah
items.description: The Adelaide Festival Corporation, which oversees Adelaide Writers' Week, has apologised to Palestinian Australian author Randa Abdel-Fattah and says she will be invited to speak at its next event in 2027.

items.title: Quiz: Think you can price a renovation? These home owners thought so too
items.description: It's a familiar story on design shows. Home owners launch into building projects with budgets and timelines that don't always match their lofty ambitions. Take our quiz to measure your renovation planning skills.

items.title: 'Guerilla' Adelaide writers' festival could get council support
items.description: Adelaide City Council will consider supporting an alternative literary festival following the cancellation of the 2026 Adelaide Writers' Week.

items.title: Australia making defence investments on the expected frontline of a China conflict
items.description: Experts say these agreements are clear signs of how important an ally the Philippines is becoming in the Indo-Pacific region amid jitters of US security guarantees.

items.title: De Minaur to face former Aus Open semifinalist in brutal draw
items.description: In the first round, the world number six will face off against Matteo Berrettini, a former Australian Open semifinalist — a place De Minaur has never progressed to himself.

items.title: Complaints roll in as record crowds watch qualifiers in AO 'Opening Week'
items.description: The Australian Open has smashed attendance records in what is being marketed as "Opening Week", featuring fan events and qualifying matches, but the main draw does not start until Sunday.

items.title: How the new passport rules for UK dual citizens will work
items.description: Your guide to new UK and Ireland passport rules for dual citizens and general entry changes beginning in February.

items.title: 10-year wait for a home in Alice Springs as public housing sits vacant
items.description: Public housing in Alice Springs is sitting vacant and in disrepair while residents wait up to a decade to be allocated a home.

items.title: New low-security prison compound opened for female inmates in Darwin
items.description: A newly refurbished compound at the Darwin Correctional Centre will next week open to accommodate low-security female prisoners, giving them greater separation from men at the prison precinct.

items.title: US announces second phase of Gaza ceasefire plan
items.description: With little fanfare, the White House has announced "phase two" of the Gaza ceasefire has begun — at least, in terms of how it views the situation with the war-ravaged territory.
